risks: Slow charge, 20+ hours to charge bus, Likely will not meet operational needs

opportunities: Lower cost for charger, utility upgrades and replacement parts; Easy to service/swap out; Good fit for buses charging overnight; Availability of replacement parts; Options for simultaneous charging that splits the power (kW); Can be remote managed
risks: May not meet operational needs if mid-day charging is needed to complete routes; Not V2G/bi-directional capable; May not meet bus minimum voltage requirements; Vehicle manufacturers possibly moving away from L2 (removing onboard inverters)

opportunities: Lower cost for charger, utility upgrades and replacement parts; Easy to service/swap out; Good fit for buses charging overnight; Availability of replacement parts; Options for simultaneous charging that splits the power (kW); Can be remote managed
risks: May not meet operational needs if mid-day charging is needed to complete routes; Not V2G/bi-directional capable; May not meet bus minimum voltage requirements; Vehicle manufacturers possibly moving away from L2 (removing onboard inverters)

opportunities: Middle ground for cost and charging speed (between L2 and DCFC); Can be V2G/bi-directional capable; Increases operational flexibility with ability to mid-day charge more quickly than L2 chargers; Wallbox versions available that can be easier to install due to wall mounting and replace than higher powered DC chargers requiring ground pads and trenching; Can be connected to : 1 phase 200 - 240 V AC +/-10 % (60 Hz), 3 phase 480 V AC +/-10 % (60 Hz); Options for simultaneous charging that splits the power (kW); Can be remote managed
risks: Higher equipment and infrastructure costs than L2 chargers; May result in electricity cost increases due to higher peaks and demand charges; Requires potentially costly utility upgrades; Possible for delays and extended wait times due to limited supply of switchgears and transformers; Cords are heavier and more difficult to maneuver; Parts and ports more fragile and easier to damage; Replacement parts more expensive and can take longer to replace; Can be harder to service especially in rural locations with limited service technicians; All above issues can lead to longer and increased downtimes compared to L2 AC chargers

opportunities: Can be V2G/bidirectional capable; Future proofing with DC charger if industry moves away from inverters on buses; Increases operational flexibility with ability to charge quickly mid-day for longer routes or larger battery capacity buses; Options for simultaneous charging that splits the power (kW); Can be remote managed
risks: More expensive than L2 AC chargers (5x+); May result in electricity cost increases due to higher peaks and demand charges; Charging station footprint can be large (refrigerator size) and a challenge for space-constrained depots; May degrade battery more quickly; May not be compatible with buses - need to check maximum vehicle acceptance rate of bus; May complicate operations if sharing fast charger across buses (not 1:1 bus to charger) - once bus is finished charging, will need to manually unplug and plug into next bus or move bus to the charger; Requires potentially costly utility upgrades; Possible delays and extended wait times due to limited supply of switchgears and transformers; Cords are heavier and more difficult to maneuver; Parts and ports more fragile and easier to damage; Replacement parts more expensive and can take longer to replace; Can be harder to service especially in rural locations with limited service technicians; All above issues can lead to longer and increased downtimes compared to L2 AC chargers

opportunities: Options for simultaneous charging that splits the power (kW) - School buses currently cannot charge over 150 kW so would be splitting the power to use these at full capacity; Options for pairing with solar (need check details of this); Can be remote managed; Includes innovative charging solution technologies that combines battery storage and charger (No peaks or demand charges as the vehicle is charging from the battery which is charged at an L2 level. This also avoids costly grid upgrades, it can be moved easily with an above-the-ground wiring solution)
risks: Extremely high upfront cost for technology and expensive maintenance, unaffordable without significant grant funding; Interoperability (as it hasn't been tested yet) and high upfront cost; If not the combined battery storage system, it may result in electricity cost increases due to higher peaks and demand charges
